faqs.question: Les étrangers peuvent-ils acheter un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can purchase Spanish property without residency requirements or citizenship restrictions. Non-EU citizens require NIE (Spanish tax identification number) obtainable through local police or Spanish embassy offices. Banking requirements include Spanish bank account opening (facilitated by property purchase documentation). Inheritance and tax planning benefit from specialized legal counsel familiar with international property ownership protocols. Purchase timelines typically span 6-8 weeks from offer acceptance through completion.

faqs.question: Quels sont les frais d'achat d'un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Purchase costs in Spain typically total 10-12% above listed property prices. Transfer tax (ITP) ranges 6-8% depending on regional location. Notary fees average 1.5-2% of purchase price. Property registry fees (0.5-1%) and surveyor costs (€300-500) complete legal documentation requirements. Mortgage arrangement fees (1-2%) apply if securing financing. Real estate agent commissions (typically 3%) are often negotiable or vendor-paid. Complete cost transparency requires itemized quotes from legal counsel prior to purchase commitment.

faqs.question: Combien coûtent les taxes foncières en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Les taxes foncières annuelles (IBI - Impuesto sobre Bienes Inmuebles) average 0.4-1.1% of cadastral property value annually. Non-resident property taxes add approximately 1% annually on declared property value. Capital gains tax applies to resale profits: 19% for EU residents, 24% for non-residents (though Spain-UK tax treaty provides modifications). Rental income taxes require professional accounting: non-residents face 24% withholding on net rental income. Comprehensive tax planning through Spanish accountants and international tax counsel optimizes fiscal efficiency for foreign investors.

faqs.question: Ai-je besoin d'un visa pour acheter un bien en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: No visa is required specifically to purchase Spanish property. However, extended stays beyond 90-day tourist allowances require residency permits (Visa de Residencia) demonstrating financial resources (typically €27,792 annually) or EU membership. Non-EU investors without Spanish employment may require passive income documentation from investments, pensions, or savings. Digital Nomad Visas (1-year renewable) support remote workers with €2,300 monthly income documentation. Residency and visa requirements depend on nationality and intended stay duration rather than property ownership itself.
